text: I recently came across a statistic that
said about 75% of all self-made
billionaires had some sort of direct
sales experience before making their
fortune as someone who spent years as a
door-to-door salesman
I can definitely see why this is the
case so in today's video I'm gonna show
you exactly why having experience in
sales can lead to massive amounts of
success for you down the line and it
really comes down to three skills that
it cultivates now before we get started
I do want to thank my sponsor this week
Squarespace for making this video
possible
they helped me renovate my website
improvement pill dotnet which you guys
can go to to access my reading list and
much much more
the first thing that you learn from
working in direct sales is a strong
belief in work ethic most direct sales
jobs operate on commission which means
you get paid depending on how much you
sell and since customers aren't handed
to you you have to actively look for
them by making calls by sending out
emails or even knocking on doors this
means in a direct sales environment if
you worked harder you would generally
make more money and seeing this happen
on a day-to-day basis causes you to
develop a very strong belief in work
ethic now you might be thinking well
yeah that's common sense everyone knows
that working harder means you'll be
rewarded more but the truth is most
people don't really believe in work
ethic they just say they do most people
work jobs where it doesn't really matter
how hard you work for example a cashier
who serves five more customers per hour
than average still gets paid the same
amount as any other cashier a nurse who
goes out of her way to help patients
still gets paid the same amount as any
other nurse a public schoolteacher who
works his butt off to come up with
inspiring lessons for his students makes
the same as the teacher next door who
teaches straight from the textbook when
you work in a place that doesn't reward
work I think you stopped believing in it
and will found a strong internal belief
in work ethic you'll find it very
difficult to work hard when you actually
need to you don't have the internal
belief or the discipline needed to chase
after your goals on the other hand if
you spent a decent chunk of time in
sales you start to believe that the
harder you work the more you'll get in
turn this makes you more discipline and
more willing to work hard on something
that may or may not reward you so it's
no surprise that most self-made
billionaires have some sort of sales
experience there simply aren't many
places besides sales where you can
cultivate a strong belief in work ethic
the second skill that you learn is
social skills when I was doing
door-to-door sales I would knock on a
door and if somebody opened up I would
have about five minutes to convince them
that I was a good person
this meant my social skills had to be
fine-tuned I had a sound confident or
else they wouldn't take me seriously I
had a show that I cared about them in
order for them to trust me and on top of
all of that I had to be funny and
relatable in order for them to even want
to help me I basically had to become
their friend in about five minutes and
the same applies for every other sort of
the req sales job out there if your
social skills are not fine-tuned if you
cannot establish a good relationship in
a short period of time you will not make
the sale well how does this relate to
self-made billionaires well it's simple
if you're a likeable person people will
want to interact with you this means
that potential customers are much more
likely to buy your stuff other business
owners are much more likely to want to
work with you and most importantly
you'll have a large network there's a
famous saying that goes like this
your network is your net worth this is
because the more people in your network
the more people who like you enough that
they're willing to help you the more
resources you have it's almost
impossible to build a billion-dollar
Empire by yourself but if you have help
from dozens of other powerful people it
becomes much much easier working in
sales forces you to learn the same
social skills needed to eventually grow
this sort of network the third and final
skill you learn is dealing with
rejection when you're doing door-to-door
sales you don't really have any sort of
supervision there's no boss looking over
your shoulder to make sure that you
knock out more doors or make more calls
and because of this there's usually an
internal struggle going on in your head
throughout
des there's a part of you that knows you
need to knock on more doors in order to
get a sale but there's also a part of
you that's constantly telling you to
give up to blame the neighborhood to
blame the weather to blame the product
and just call it a day all of this has a
direct link with how you take rejection
rejection comes in many shapes and forms
especially for a direct salesman I've
been yelled at I've had doors slammed in
my face I've had people call the cops on
me I even had someone tell their dog to
attack me the first couple of times are
really really affected me I remember one
incident early on in my career where I
got cursed out by an old lady
I had a sit down on a park bench for
about an hour before I could force
myself to knock on doors again but over
time as I continued to work in sales I
started to become more resistant to
rejection it got to the point where even
if I was chased out of a building
I would laugh it off and immediately
knock on another door most people
nowadays are extremely scared of
rejection we're scared to talk to girls
because we're afraid of being called the
creep we're scared to follow our
passions because we're afraid of looking
like a fool we care so much about what
other people think that we stick to what
everyone else does because that's the
only way to really avoid rejection by
doing things that are so normal so
boring so plain that you don't risk any
chance of getting rejected the problem
with this is that success can only be
achieved if you take risks you must be
brave enough to face your fear of
rejection not only that you must also be
able to continue trying after getting
rejected over and over again working in
sales can really really change your life
because of three skills that it teaches
it teaches you to truly believe that
working harder will give you better
results it teaches you the social skills
you need to build up a business and it
teaches you how to deal with rejection
with negativity and push forward
regardless of what others are saying
it's no wonder that 75% of all self-made
billionaires have some sort of sales
experience in the past because these
three skills are crucial for reaching
that level of success again I would like
